AWS / Apps



AWS Services and Costs
Services Overview and Tips
Cost Management

  • AWS Billing Alarms
  • AWS Cost and Usage Report
  • AWS Budget
    • 2 free budgets
  • Resource Group and Cost Allocation Tag
  • AWS Tagging Strategies
  • Trusted Advisor
  • EC2/S3 Cost Strategies
  • General Best Practices / Solutions Architecture principles
  • Well Architected Tool
AWS Billing Alarms
  • For overall account cost monitoring - get billing alerts by emails
  • Must enable (SA demo)

AWS Cost and Usage Report
  • GUI tool to view and analyse
    • MTD costs and usage
    • forecasted costs
    • get recommendations for reserved instances
  • shows costs per time windows and per service

AWS Budget
  • Create budget and get notifications when costs are exceeding - 3 types: Usage, Cost, Reservation
  • Similar to AWS Cost explorer but allows more details, eg:
  • I want my data transfer into S3 to be < 1GB / month
  • I want my t2.micro instances in eu-west-2 with tag CHEAP to be < 10 / month

AWS Resource Group
  • To group any resources (eg. EC2) based on tags (dev/prod), cfn stack tags, etc.
  • AWS Resource Group includes the Tag Editor to tag ALL AWS resources for cost management
  • Also very helpful to see all AWS resources within the account
  • Track cost/usage per set of resources for detailed cost reporting (eg. costs of Env/Dev/Prod resources)

Cost Allocation Tag
  • Enable to automatically have aws tags created (eg. aws: CreatedBy)
    • aws tags can only be seen by the Billing & Cost console (not directly in the different services)
    • User Tags: defined by the user, start with Prefix "user:" will appear in the Billing & Cost Console as well
  • DevOps demo for an EC2 tagged "Environment: Dev" -> allows to slice & dice costs by tags in the Cost Explorer and reports

AWS Tagging strategies
  • https://www.cloudforecast.io/blog/aws-tagging-best-practices/
  • Track costs per department / environments etc
  • CodeDeploy, CloudFormation to know what resources those services manage
  • Security (tagged based access control) to give access to the resources tagged "dev"
  • Use consistent case sensitive format across all tags
  • Technical tags: Name, App ID, App Role, Cluster, Environment, Version
  • Automation tags: Date/Time, Security (Entryption o rnot)
  • Business Tags: Owner, Cost Center, Customer, Project
  • Security tags: Confidentiality, Governance...

Trusted Advisor
  • Global service -> to use it as a source in CW Events: switch to N. Virginia
  • Analyse all account and gives high level recommendations: Costs, Performance, Security, Fault Tolerance, Service Limits
    • Though requires a support plans for all features - only some core checks are free
    • Enable weekly email notifications for Costs, Security, and Operations
    • Great to see which services are used
  • DevOps demo
    • Lambda to Stop EC2 instance when "Low Utilisation" Trusted Advisor source triggers a CW Events
    • Resize instance type automatically based on usage
    • Check if Bucket are public (cannot check object level)
    • Check when about to reach service limits and trigger CW Event, etc.

EC2 Cost Strategies
  • Use Spot instance / Spot fleet when possible - support standalone EC2
  • Reserved Instance

S3 Cost Strategies
  • Compress objects before upload to S3
  • S3 Select
  • S3 Lifecycle rules to transition objects between Tiers
    • Use Intelligent Tiering, S3 One Zone IA, Glacier,...
  • S3 Requester pays (from a bucket policy)

General Best Practices / Solutions Architecture principles
  • SA Pro - great slide 112 showing common services
  • Force at the account level to have new resources created with tags using SCP - Use Tag Editor to tag existing resources. Create cost allocation tags to define the cost center and project ID. Use SCPs to restrict resource creation that do not have the cost center and project ID on the resource.
  • Review SA Pro Diagrams of common architectures (slide 195)
    • ALB + ASG, ALB + ECS on Fargate, ALB + Lambda, API GTW + Lambda, etc.
  • Separate static resources (S3, CF) from dynamic ones (EC2, ALB) - SA Pro 228
  • Create separate secure AWS account for all logging
  • SA on AWS - SA Professional slide 112 showing all layers
    • DNS, Web, CDN, Compute, Caching, DB, Decoupling, Storage
  • Handling extremes rates with caching @edge and backend (SA Pro 254)
  • Documentation
    • Create a full SA diagram such as https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/architecture/wordpress-best-practices-on-aws/

Well Architected Tool
  • Suggests architectures based on survey questions + read more about the 5 pillars at SA A. 651
    • https://aws.amazon.com/architecture/
    • https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/

Security

  • IAM, STS, Policies
  • Access Advisor
  • KMS
    • 20k API calls (encrypt/decrypt) pm
  • Disaster recovery strategies
    • Back up & restore is cheap
    • Pilot light is reasonably cheap
  • AWS Data Lifecycle Manager
  • AWS Inspector
    • 90 days free only
  • AWS Health
    • Free
  • AWS Organisation + SCP

IAM
  • Never use root account, never store IAM key credentials but on personal computers
  • Best practice to use GetSessionToken from STS
    • Used @Eigen
    • get temporary credentials
    • must define specific IAM role for this user
  • Grant least privilege
    • Define very specific IAM user/group policies 
    • Define very specific IAM role policies for each service
      • EC2s, Lambdas, CodeBuild etc. to have their own roles
      • so they can assume the role and perform specific actions.
      • A user can assign an IAM role to a service only if that user has the iam:PassRole/GetRole IAM permission
  • Users: Long term credentials
  • Roles: Short-term credentials (uses STS under the hood)
  • 4 types of policies
    • AWS managed policies
      • for "power users" (dev leads) PowerUserAccess, and administrators (AdministratorAccess)
    • Customer managed policies:
      • defined automatically at services creation
      • best practice, re-usable, applied to many users (principals)
      • version controlled + rollback possible
    • Inline Policies:
      • strict one to one relationship between the policy and user (principal)
      • deleting the IAM user will automatically delete the inline policy
      • They can be found in the "Users" section, because tied to one user
    • Resource-based policies for S3, SNS, SQS
      • Best practice, preferable over roles (slide 13 SA Professional)
      • Because when you assume an S3 Role, you "give up" your original permissions
      • With Bucket policies, one can keep his original role
  • IAM Permission boundaries
    • Restrict a user/group to only have access to X and Y services
  • Look at IAM policies examples! (SO 395)
    • STS for cross account access
    • IAM PassRole
    • MFA, etc. 
    • https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies_examples.html
  • IAM Policies conditions, some examples of operators
    • StringEquals, NumericNotEquals, (Not)IpAddress for S3 bucket access, ArnEquals, ArnLike, Null, etc.
  • IAM Policies variables and tags
    • ${aws:username} -> allows for S3 users to have their own prefix
    • ${aws:SourceIp}, userid, SourceInstanceARN, etc.
  • STS to assume a role (@Eigen)
    • Must define an IAM role to be assumed in the account
    • Then define which principal can assume it (Azure AD user)
    • Use the AWS STS service to assume the role
    • Temporary access 15mn up to 1 hour

Access Advisor
  • To see permissions granted and when last accessed - allows for least priviledge

KMS
  • Must be used anytime sensitive information is shared (credentials, private keys of SSL, ...)
  • Seamlessly integrated with EBS, S3, RDS, SSM... and fully integrated with IAM for authorization
  • 2 types of KMS Keys
    • AWS Managed - free
      • tied up to one service
    • Customer Manager Key (CMK) - 1$/month
      • can be used for multiple services
      • can Create/Rotate/Enable/Disable key
      • can be created/imported 
  • Policies
    • Key Policy to allow users to use the Key = WHO can use the key
      • Default KMS Key Policy: root user (whole account) can access and use this key
      • Custom KMS Key Policy: Define specific users and roles (services) that can access the key + who can administer the key
    • IAM Policy allows the API Calls = WHERE it can be used
  • If data to encrypt is > 4KB -> use envelope encryption, only for CMK

DR strategies
Think of a "Back up and restore" (cheapest) strategy and test it
  • What is my Recovery Point Objective vs. Recovery Time Objective
  • Backup & restore / Pilot Light / Warm standby / Hot site approach
  • Monkey chaos testing
  • Backup
    • schedule EBS / RDS snapshots
    • regular pushes to S3 / S3 IA / Glacier with Lifecycle policies
  • HA
    • Route53 to migrate DNS over multiple regions + R53 healthcheck tied up to CW alarms
    • Enable HA for RDS, ElastiCache, S3
  • Replication
    • RDS / S3 replication (SRR, CRR)
  • Automation
    • CloudFormation to recreate a whole new environment (and cfn stackset for multi region deployments)
    • Recover / reboot instances with CW alarms
    • Lambda for any customised automation

AWS Data Lifecycle Manager
  • Automate EBS snapshots (daily)
  • Incremental, so should be cheap

Inspector
  • Assess vulnerabilities on EC2 instances (not AMIs) and provide recommendations on software updates 
    • Can set recurring assessments (eg. every 7 days) - using CW Event rule with Inspector as a Target
      • Network assessments (agent not required)
      • Host assessments (agent required)
    • Can send SNS notification about findings reported etc.
  • Requires AWS inspector agent to be installed - can be done via SSM  using Amz Linux 2 + Instance role for SSM (see DevOps demo)

AWS Health
  • Service Health Dashboard vs. Personal Health Dashboard for your own resources
  • Very cool out of the box cfn template which is demo-ed in DevOps course: 
    • github.com/aws/aws-health-tools/tree/-master/automated-actions/AWS_RISK_CREDENTIALS_EXPOSED
    • Use CW event with Health as a source and even type "AWS_RISK_CREDENTIALS_EXPOSED"
    • Step functions and lambdas to automatically delete compromised IAM keys, and send reports on potentially compromised services (used by this key). 

AWS Organization
  • Consists of 1 Master account, then organised with accounts grouped into OU (by department for eg).
  • Consolidated billing features (all accounts treated as one)
  • Can use Service Control Policies to whitelist/blacklist services at account/Org Unit level
  • Use AWS Resource Access Manager to share resources between accounts
Networking

  • VPC
  • Subnet
  • NAT GTW vs. NAT Instance
  • NACL vs. SGs
  • VPC Peering
  • VPC Endpoints
  • Site to Site VPN vs. DX

VPC Basics
  • Check Solutions Architect Associate - great slide 524 showing all network components in a VPC
    CIDR = range of IP addresses, eg. 192.168.0.0/26 will give 64 IPs (192.168.0.0 - 192.168.0.63)
  • IPv4 (running out) vs. IPv6 (huge range of IPs) for IoTs
  • Private IP only accessible from a private network (home, corporate, aws)
    • Big networks: 10.0.0.0 10.255.255.255 (10.0.0.0/8)
    • AWS network: 172.16.0.0 172.31.255.255 (172.16.0.0/12)
    • Home network: 192.168.0.0 192.168.255.255 (192.168.0.0/16)
  • Public IPs = all the rests (accessible from the public internet)
  • VPC = AWS private network defined by a CIDR range
  • Subnets are subsets of the VPC
    • All instances in a subnet get a private IP
    • Subnets can be private or public
      • Private subnets have a RT 0.0.0.0/0 ->  NAT GTW (not free) for private instances to access public www
      • Public subnets have a RT 0.0.0.0/0 -> IGW - All instances must have IPv4
  • Route tables to direct traffic between subnets / VPC (most specific rules takes priority)
  • NACL vs. SGs covered in EC2 notes
  • VPC Flow logs to log internet traffic at the VPC/subnet/ENI level
    • Capture denied traffic
    • Send logs to CW Logs / S3

VPC Peering
  • Connect 2 VPCs (not transitive), not overlapping CIDRs, inter-regions/accounts

VPC Endpoints
  • For Private resources (eg. EC2s. Lambda) to access public services (S3, DynDB, CW etc)
    • Remove the need to use IGW and NAT
    • Reduce network costs as compared to public traffic between EC2 and S3/DynDB
  • VPC Endpoints Gateway for S3 & DynDB and VPC Endpoint Interface for the rest
  • Cannot be extended via VPC peering or shared with other accounts
  • VPC Endpoints policies to control access from private resources to "public/global" services
    • Only for the private route - does not apply when one access the service "publicly"
    • S3 bucket policy can allow/deny resources at the VPC level, or Endpoint level
    • SA Pro slide for connecting private instance to S3 privately (slide 459)

Corporate
  • Site to Site VPN
    • To connect corporate network (via CGW) to a AWS VPC (via a VPG)
  • Direct Connect
    • Provide the same as Site-to-Site VPN, but it's a dedicated connection, more stable / bandwidth / expensive
    • Data can optionally be encrypted (on top of being a private connection already)

App Deployment, HA, Resilience

  • EC2
    • t2.micro x1
  • Elastic IP
    • Expensive, do not use!
  • EBS
    • total 30GB (gp2)
  • ALB
    • 1 running pm
  • Target Group
    • Free
  • ASG & Launch Templates
    • Free, pay for underlying EC2s
  • AWS Certificate Manager
    • Free
  • Route53
    • hosted zone is $0.50 pm
  • ECS
    • TBC
  • Fargate
    • Can use spot instances!
  • Elastic Beanstalk
    • Underlying services
EC2
  • For HA and scalability - Section 5 SysOps:
    • 1. create target group
    • 2. ELB
    • 3. ASG
  • For easy cheap auto recovery: Use CW Alarm StatusCheckFailed_System (DevOps slide 120)
    • Recovery will lead to same private, public, EIP, metadata, placement group
  • Instance type / placement
    • Spot fleets are much better as they allow to request automatically for the spot instances with the lowest price (unlike spot instances)
    • Use Placement Groups - Spread for HA, Cluster for Low Latency, Partition for Big data etc.
  • EBS
    • Encrypt EBS at rest (gp2)
    • EBS snapshots to be automated using Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager
      • Snapshots are incremental! only backup new changes (kind of cheap then)
    • if high wait time or slow response from EC2 > increase IOPS
  • CW Metrics
    • VolumeIdleTime, VolumeQueueLength, BurstBalance
  • Provision instance
    • Custom AMI with preinstalled packages (docker, helm, curl, jq, whatever) + installed django app? (no docker)
    • User Data script for dynamic configuration at instance launch time (eg. start webserver etc)
  • Security groups
    • Attached at the EC2 level
    • Stateful: Traffic that goes in/out will also goes out/in
    • Can reference other SGs, EC2, ELBs, or CIDR ranges
    • Allow traffic from ELB only, and SSH from specific IP - or no ssh
  • NACL
    • Attached to the subnet level (before traffic reaches SG)
    • Stateless: Inbound and outbound rules must be defined
    • Can only reference a CIDR range
    • Easy way to blacklist / whitelist IPs before it gets to the subnet
  • Instance role
    • eg. Lambda access for EC2 (put/delete to rds) for application to manage photos
    • If ASG, IAM role attached to the ASG will get assigned to EC2s
  • Elastic IP - try to avoid using it (and it comes with a cost too)

ALB
  • Amazing DevOps demo
    • HTTPS with domain name on ALB from scratch (incl. buying the domain name)
    • store SSL in ACM
    • Load SSL certificate to ALB there to have connection termination and reduce load on EC2s
    • Can have multiple SSL certificates per ELB using Server Name Indication
  • Allows to expose single point of access (public DNS) and handles failures (Healthcheck) in downstream private instances + HA
  • ELBs can be either internal (private) or external (public)
  • Multiple EC2 behind an ALB means we have to manage session data
    • Enable stickiness to keep session data
    • or use DynamoDB to store cookies
  • Target Group & Healthchecks
    • Needs to be created before launching an ELB, used to group EC2s, ECS, Lambda, or IP addresses
    • Healthcheck are defined at the Target Group level (or ELB level?)
    • Healthchecks will replace unhealthy / unresponsive instances
  • Routing to different TGs, based on
    • URL path (/users), URL hostname (gbournique.com), or URL Query String Headers (<hostname>/?test=2)
  • Cross Zone Load Balance enabled by default on ALB
  • Can enable LB stickiness to redirect same user to same instance (though session data on DynDB/ElastiCache is better)
  • Monitoring
    • Enable access logs to S3/CW
    • Send ALB metrics to CW + logs (detailed info about incoming requests) to S3/CW
      • incoming connections
      • error codes as % over time with custom metrics
      • performance, etc.
    • Send TG metrics (# of healthy/unhealthy instances)

ASG
  • ASG Settings to enable HA: min/max/desired=1 and AZ>=2
  • Can terminate instances & restart them when they're marked as unhealthy by the ELB
  • Scaling Policies
    • Scheduled actions
      • to scale in/out based on schedule: for eg. set desired instances to 0 at night?
    • Target Tracking Policy
      • Built-in metrics: CPU average, avg network in, # requests on the ELB / per EC2 instance
        • Eg. Desired avg CPU 60% will create 2 CW alarms behind the scenes for when to scale in and out
      • DevOps demo: Trigger stress CPU utilisation to 100% with utility and see scale out/in where target avg CPU = 60%:
        • sudo amazon-linux-extras install epel -y && sudo yum install stress -y
        • sudo stress --cpu 2 --timeout 180
    • Simple Scaling Policy
      • Create an alarm in advanced, eg. if ALARM state, add/remove X instances
      • more involved, also more flexibility with custom metrics (p. 90 SE, eg. connected users to the app)
    • Step Scaling Policy
      • Use a created alarm, ability to define custom intervals: what to do when CPU >60, >70, >80 etc...
    • Important scaling settings
      • cooldown - default 5mn: time before another scaling activity can get triggered
      • warm-up: time before the average CPU in the group metric collection gets updated after a scale out event
  • Healthchecks integration at the ALB level
    • Healthcheck must be simple AND only involves the EC2 (should not check for underlying DB connection)
    • Create ALB -> create Target group to be instance based + healthcheck path, eg. /health.html
    • Go back to ASG settings and add the target group + change healthcheck settings from "EC2" to "ELB"
    • DevOps Demo showing failed healthcheck will remove the faulty instance and create a new one
    • Target group -> can set a Slow start duration so that the newly created instance will NOT receive full capacity of requests straight away
  • Deployment strategies for ASG + ELB - SA Pro slides 126+
    • In Place: CodeDeploy will "uninstall" v1 and install v2 on all existing instances -> app updated on instance so could be buggy
    • Rolling (+w/ add. batches): Keep the same ASG/ELB + Create a v2 instance, then terminating v1's - deployment to fresh instances - more likely to succeed
    • Replace (immutable): Create a new ASG with v2's, when all done, delete the old ASG with v1's
    • Blue/Green: Create new ASG AND new ELB, + can use R53 to send % traffic to both ELBs at the same time
  • Monitoring / Troubleshooting
    • Troubleshoot ASG instances
      • add "Suspended Processes" settings, eg. looking into some "unhealthy" instance by suspending its ReplaceUnhealthy process
      • Can also detach instances from the Target group, and a new one will be registered / launched automatically
      • Right click on the ASG instance -> "standby mode" = stays in the Target Group, but not reachable by the ELB
      • Can also enable "Scale in protection" to prevent removing a specific instance if scale in event
    • Lifecycle hooks, use cases:
      • Launch hook to configure application before "InService"
      • Termination hook to take snapshot or retrieve logs
    • ASG as a source for CW events
      • send SNS / slack notification via Lambda for instances launched / terminated / whatever
    • CW metrics: GroupMin/MaxSize, GroupDesiredCapactiy, etc. (SO 110) - can also monitor at EC2 level (1mn/5mn)
  • DevOps demo: ASG & LC + CFN 
    • CreationPolicy to check if ASG first deployed as expected: will signal back that all desired instances were created
    • UpdatePolicy needs to be set in cfn, so that uploading new cfn template version will roll up new version
      • see deployment strategies for ASG + ELB
  • DevOps demo: ASG + CFN + CodeDeploy
    • In the previous demo, we used the Apache server deployed via User Data script which is relatively simple
    • For more complex application, can use CodeDeploy
      • cfn-init to install CodeDeploy agent via the User Data for the EC2s for the ASG
      • create CodeDeploy application
        • Create deployment group using our ASG with "inplace" deployment to deploy the application on the current instances
        • online repository from s3 (gzip containing appspec.yml)
    • Now, ASG scaling out will automatically deploy the application to new instances

Launch Template
  • Used by ASG to create new instances
  • LT better than Launch Configuration
    • Allows to have template versioning
    • Able to provision both on-demand and spot instances! much more powerful
  • LT "parents" to inherit base configurations (Nested LCs): Create a parent/base one (basic configs) + custom LCs coming on top
  • LT will define
    • AMI, Instance type, SGs, Instance role, storage..
    • User data script to install latest release of an application
    • selected subnet(s) for HA
    • Target Group, number of min/max/desired instances,
    • ELB healthcheck type: ELB level vs. EC2 level
  • To update an ASG, re-create a new launch configuration... best to use Launch templates instead which have versioning
  • Can be defined in CFN?
  • DevOps demo - "Create ASG from template"

ACM Certificate manager
  • Remove the pain of manually managing certificates
  • Store SSL certificates
  • Load them to ELBs, CF, API Gateways
  • Renew them automatically!

Route 53
  • Prefer Alias (hostname to AWS resource) instead of CNAME (hostname to hostname)
    • Alias works for root hostnames gbournique.com instead of having to use www.gbournique.com for CNAME 
  • Set low TTL (more traffic on DNS but not outdated records, so it redirects to the right resources/IPs

  • Use routing policies
    • Failover routing policy to redirect to S3 website down page
    • Weighted routing policy can be used to test traffic to a new app (B/G)
    • Lantency, geo, etc.
  • Healthchecks at R53 level for automated DNS failovers, based on
    • Triggered by
      • either simple healthchecks: text in the first 5KB of a path, eg. /health
      • or custom CW Alarms for full control (eg. detect throttles from DB, etc)
        • because private resources within a VPN cannot be healthchecked by global R53
    • Target:
      • CW Alarms

ECS
  • ECS uses ASG behind the screen to spin up new instances
  • Definitely much easier as a "single" docker deployment
    • For multi docker, maybe best to use Beanstalk with a Dockerrun.aws.json file
  • direct integration with ALB, with the with the port mapping feature / dynamic port forward
    • Allows to run multiple containers on a single and across instances
    • and maximise CPU/Core utilisation
  • ECS task  to define how the container will run (~docker compose file)
    • image, ports, etc. + container memory/cpu limits, healthcheck, volume, etc.
    • After task definition is configured, run it from an ECS service
      • To ensure the number of desired tasks is running
      • To be linked with an ELB 
  • ECS auto scaling only for containers!!!
    • Similar scaling policies as for ASG
    • Does NOT scale EC2 (so it's independent to ASG)
    • EC2s must be provisioned manually, can use ASG but tricky
    • Binpack placement strategy for cost savings
  • Authorization
    • ECS Instance role used by the ECS agent on EC2, (eg. to pull from Dockherhub/ECR or send container logs to CW)
    • ECS task role defines what the containers are allowed to do (eg. talk to S3)

Fargate
  • Same as ECS but serverless! - No more EC2 to manage, only need to increase the task number to scale
  • Can use Spot Instances - check the cost?! Might be worth it over ECS
  • Fargate only have task roles (no ec2 instance roles because no EC2 to manage)

Elastic Beanstack
  • Great to "replatform" application from on-prem to cloud
  • To reproduce our 3 tier architecture easily with a developer centric view
    • Just the application code is the responsibility of the developer
    • ALB + ASG model while still having full control over the underlying resources
    • Seems easy to manage from CLI (page 308 SE), useful for CD pipeline
    • Can define CloudFormation template resources in .ebextensions to automatically provision any services
    • Webserver (ELB + EC2) vs. Worker Tier (SQS + EC2)
  • Glue everything and manage deployments / rolling update all in one view
  • Do not provision a prod RDS as part of Beanstalk, otherwise it gets deleted (unless Retain policy?) 
  • Can use in Multi Docker Container mode, which DOES use ECS, just describe where the image is and how to run it

Storage

  • S3
    • 5GB total
  • CloudFront
    • 50GB of data transfer out
  • ElasticSearch
    • t3.small.elasticsearch
  • ElastiCache
    • cache.t2.micro 
  • RDS (PostgreSQL)
    • db.t2.micro
  • DynamoDB (NoSQL)
    • 25GB total
  • Cognito User Pools
    • 50k monthly active users
S3
  • Store blobs: image, videos, files, any large objects
  • Anti patterns: lots of small files, dynamic content from website, POSIX file system (use EFS)Use prefixes (paths) to create a semblance of folder structure - eg. (based on time / username) (p. 178 SE)
  • S3 static website
    • Display a static html page for the DNS to fail over to (eg. when the whole stack is down at night)
  • Security
    • Enable Versioning sooner than later!
    • Encryption at rest with
      • SSE-KMS
      • SSE-S3/AES-266 (aws managed)
      • SSE-C (encryption in cloud but AWS won't store key) - HTTPS required, because client sends encryption key
      • Client side encryption (upload encrypted data)
    • Encryption in Flight with SSL (HTTPS endpoint)
      Policies: Actual permission are evaluated as
      • User based: IAM Policy vs. Resource Based: Bucket Policy (SE653)
        Policies use cases:
        • Only allow access from a VPC (require an S3 endpoint gateway or DX, VPC Peering)
        • Enforce bucket level / object level encryption, MFA delete, In flight encryption SSL... (SE690)
        • Only from Origin Access Identify (CloudFront), grand access to other account
        • Dynamic policies to give "folder" access to specific users (SE658)
        • more use cases: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/example-bucket-policies.html
    • S3 MFA delete and S3 Object Lock
    • CRR and SRR (entire bucket or by prefix) to destination bucket
    • Pre-signed URLs to share temporary download/upload links for users outside AWS + can also generated signed URL dymaically
    • VPC Endpoint Gateway for S3 to be accessed from private subnets
  • Monitoring
    • Store S3 Access Logs to another bucket or CW logs
    • CloudTrail to access Object level API access
  • Cost
    • Create S3 lifecycle rules to move objects between different classes based on usage, or expire object after X days
    • S3 select for server side filtering
  • S3 Event Notifications to integrate with SQS/SNS/Lambda
    • Automated actions on object creation, deletion, restore, etc.
    • Object level, while CW Events is Object and Bucket logging level (which requires CT to be enabled)

CloudFront
  • Unlike other services listed here, CF is used @Edge (globally) to cache data
  • Origins
    • To serve image files located on S3
    • static website hosted on S3 to fail over to
    • Custom HTTP origin (ALB, EC2, API GTW, any HTTP backend) for global applications
      • to benefit from caching at edge, and limit requests to ALB (417 SA)
  • Configure TTL for caching (1sec -> 1year)
  • Check/update cache based on Headers, Cookies, or Query string parameters -> find a good caching strategy
  • CF Monitoring is great - Plenty of interesting data such as
    • requests per day, cache hit / misses, bytes transferred, error codes, popiular objects, top referrers...
    • shows a good insights on website usage.
  • Improved security with CF OAI - allows to make S3 fully private with a strict bucket policy
  • Can be used as an ingress to upload files to S3 
    • CloudFront signed URL to give secure access to any private HTTP backend (ALB, etc) - not the same as S3 signed URL!
  • Can use Lambda@Edge to add Authentication and Authorisation checks at Edge 

ElasticSearch
  • For any searching feature + managed Kibana for real time dashboards - must try
  • Not serverless - must provision EC2
  • Use cases
    • Log Analytics (from CW Logs - either application or system logs)
    • Application monitoring
    • Search items from ElasticSearch, then retrieve them from DynamoDB
    • Full text searching features
    • Clickstream Analytics, Indexing

ElastiCache
  • Cached data for potentially high reads with common requests (though CF preferred) 
  • Must provision an EC2 instance
  • Involves heavy code refactoring to use ElastiCache (eg. Session data)
  • MUST be used for retrieve session data (page 133 SE) - set cache TTL
  • Write through vs Lazy loading strategies (p. 136 SE)
  • Placed in the private subnet, with a SG only open to EC2s/ELB security group
  • Monitoring with CW
  • Security with KMS

RDS
  • Managed database - Postgres, MySQL, SQL Server, etc.
  • HA: 2 options
    • Multi AZ: One DNS name with automatic failover to StandBy replicas (SYNC) when primary DB not available
      • Does NOT change read/write performances though
    • Read replicas (ASYNC) - cross AZ/regions - must implemented automated workflow for automatic failover though
      • Does scales reads - useful for reporting apps to not impact main application
  • Security
    • Placed in the private subnet, security group only open to EC2s security group - no public access!
    • Enforce SSL! by editing the parameter group of the RDS database and add rds.force_ssl=1 (SO 308)
    • Enable encryption with KMS
    • Use SSM to store credentials
    • Can force SSL for data encryption in flight
    • Authentication (page 150 in SA pdf)
      • username/password can also be used for
      • or IAM based for MySQL, PostgreSQL
    • Authorization
      • happens within RDS, not IAM - who can manage the database, do X on Y table
  • Backups and Snapshots (storage on EBS gp2 or io1)
    • Enable continuous storage backup (default, automated)
      • up to 20GB free of backup/snapshots
      • WILL expire eventually 0-35 days
    • Snapshots (manual) for long term backups
      • will NOT expire
      • automated final snapshot when terminated
  • Use CLI for CI/CD pipelines!
    • Get list of db instances, Create snapshots, Describe write/read events, Reboot instance, etc. (SO 311)
  • Monitoring
    • CW metrics such as DB connections, read/write IOPS/Latency/ThroughPut, DiskQueueDepth, FreeStorageSpace, ... (SO 312)
    • RDS Events: get notified via SNS when operations, outages, etc.
    • RDS Performance Insights to check the DB load (does not work with t2.micro) - check what's the performance bottleneck (resources, sql statements, hosts, users...) - SO 313

DynamoDB
  • Google "Choosing the right DynamoDB partition key"
  • Managed NoSQL database
  • Serverless and highly scalable! No limit on storage
  • But objects must be < 400KB -> if heavy aggregation results to cache then use ElastiCache
  • Provisioned capacity (WCU/RCU, auto scaling) or On-demand for unpredictable workloads
  • DynamoDB Streams to react to changes in tables in real-time
    • Can be read by Lambda, EC2, ...
    • 24 hours retention of data
  • Security with KMS, VPC, IAM, CloudTrail
  • DynamoDB patterns
    • Store user session data to stay logged in when accessing EC2 behind ELB
    • store S3 object metadata, to be queried by ElasticSearch, then we can
      • check if object exists on S3
      • get total storage used by a customer on S3
      • list all objects with some attribute, find objects within datetime range...
    • Welcome email use case: New user details into a table > trigger DynDB stream > Lambda > SES
      • DynDB Stream triggered on inserts, modify, delete events..
      • check DevOps / Developer demos
      • must define Event Source Mapping to read from a DynamoDB Streams
  • DAX for caching ($$)
    • Solves the Hot Key problem (too many reads
    • set a good TTL on a per row basis, by adding a column and a expiration date
    • Check DevOps demo to set TTL

Cognito
  • More than just storing users...
  • Cognito User Pool to allow authentication
    • Let users sign in with Facebook with federated identities via a Hosted authentication UI (html/css customisable)
    • Add email/phone verification and password reset process + MFA
    • Login sends back a JSON web token (can be integrated with Django using lambda?)
    • Integrates with ALB or API GTW (figure out the best way for the django signin integration)
    • Can invoke a Lambda triggered synchronously on Login/Signup events
  • Cognito Identity Pools to allow authorization
    • Who can access S3, which is using STS (SA395)

Serverless / Microservices communication

  • SQS & SQS FIFO
    • 1m requests
  • SNS
    • 1m requests
  • SES
    • 62k emails pm

SQS
  • Managed serverless queue (extreme scale) for decouple services (async), fault tolerance, LB
    • Message max size 256KB (point to S3 for large messages)
    • Source: EC2, ASG, Lambda
    • Target: EC2, ASG, Lambda, or even DynamoDB (as a buffer to avoid throttling)
    • Enable long polling for cost savings: Wait X seconds before checking if new items in queue
  • SQS FIFO to respect ordering, but limited to 300 messages/s, or 3000/s with batching
  • Make sure the architecture is idempotent!
    • no adverse effect is message is processed twice by the consumer
    • eg. Upsert into DynamoDB instead of Insert
  • Can send messages by batches (1-10) when polled by a Lambda Event Source Mapping
    • Set the SQL on SQS, not Lambda
  • integrated with IAM for security
  • Use cases
    • SQS between app web tier and RDS to prevent overloading
    • SQS + ASG to scale EC2s based on SQS queue length (page 329 SA)

SNS
  • Pub/Sub to send one message to multiple consumers
  • Fanout pattern: SNS sends message to multiple SQS subscribers - also allows for delayed processing, retries
  • Subscribers can be: HTTP/S, SQS, Lambda, Emails, SMS, Mobile notifications
  • SNS for all email notifications (send to many receivers)
  • Security IAM roles
  • Monitoring: Integrates with CW Alarms, ASG notifications, S3, CF, etc
  • Streaming applications: using SQS/SNS is possible but probably more expensive than Kinesis services (Stream/Analytics/Firehose)

Serverless / Microservices

  • Lambda
    • 1m calls
  • SAM Framework
    • Free (pay for underlying resources)
  • API Gateway
    • 1m calls
  • Step Functions
    • 4k steps pm
Lambda
  • ~ Azure Function apps
  • Compute
    • Max timeout is 15mn! (default is 3 seconds)
    • CPU/RAM can be increased 128MB -> 3GB, will increase CPU as well
    • Max 1000 concurrent executions in a whole account
    • Local (temp) storage of only 512MB - Lambda can't process big files
    • Heavy config work and setup must be OUTSIDE of Lambda function handler
      • database connection, sdk initialisation, pulling dependencies
      • best to use Lambda layers for dependencies
      • Deployment package (app code + deps) must be < 250MB
  • Invocation modes
    • Synchronous
      • Error handling on client side
    • Asynchronous
      • 3 retries then send message to Lambda destination / DLQ
      • Make sure the process is idempotent (no adverse effect if action performed more than once)
    • Event Source Mapping
      • Sources can be: Kinesis Streams, SQS, SNS, DynamoDB Streams
      • This time, Lambda polls from the source, respect ordering of messages, retrieves batches of data
      • Can have Lambda destination for failed batches 
  • Versioning
    • Lambda work on $LATEST is mutable
    • Versions (~ git tags) are immutable = app code + configurations cannot be changed. Increasing number of versions
    • Must define aliases to point to versions
      • eg. DEV -> Latest, and PROD -> v1, TEST -> v2, etc. this is a manual process.
      • Lambda aliases allows to do blue/green testing by routing traffic % to 2 versions
  • Use cases
    • Integration with S3 events
      • ObjectCreated/Removed/Restore/Replication...
      • Can filter path (for eg. by file extension, or by "folder") 
      • eg. automated mage processing and output to another bucket (thumbnail creation)
    • As a CRON Job
      • eg. to ping website every X hours and check it's running (page 362)
    • Anything for automation (start/stop instances, etc.)
  • Error handling
    • use Lambda Destinations (better than DLQ), and for eg. to trigger SNS
  • Security
    • API Gateway to expose Lambda (in a Target Group) as HTTPS
    • Deploy Lambda in a VPC/private subnet, will need AWSLambdaVPCAccessExecutionRole role
    • Lambda IAM role (execution role) to talk to any service
      • eg. read from DynamoDB Streams/SQS, Push data to CW
    • Lambda Resource Based Policies (similar to S3 bucket policies)
      • who can access Lambda (principals: user(s) or account(s))
    • Lambda env variables to be stored in SSM
  • Monitoring - must have correct IAM permissions
    • Push logs / metrics to CW - some default metrics are already provided (# executions, error counts, etc.)
    • X-Ray can be enabled with a checkbox
  • CI/CD
    • Look at slide SA Pro 155 - Dev/Test/Prod stage, + CodeDeploy

SAM Framework
  • Programatically start a fresh complete lambda function
    • Test it locally via docker
    • Build & deploy it via SAM CLI which uses CloudFormation
    • Can create Lambda layers to separate dependencies from application code
    • Integrates CodeDeploy out of the box for Lambda deployments (Linear/Canary)
    • Remap the alias to new version automatically
  • Allows to create serverless services with the simple SAM Template (~CFN)
    • DynamoDB, API Gateway, Step Functions

API Gateway
  • Allows to expose
    • Lambda/Step Function as HTTP/S
    • any AWS HTTP services, eg ELB, as HTTP/S
  • + Powerful features
    • API versioning and stages (dev/prod)
    • Stages will point to different Lambda aliases
    • Rate limiting
    • Caching
    • Request/Response transformations
    • Authorization (API Keys) -> make a payable service for a client
  • Monitoring
    • Logs to show request body and parameters (full req/response logs)
    • API GTW Access Logs
    • Can enable X-Ray
    • Enable CW at the Stage level (with Log level) then can override settings on a per API basis (ERROR, DEBUG, INFO) 
  • Limits
    • 29 seconds timeout
    • 10MB max payload -> cannot process large files (best to generate pre-signed S3 URL and download it - SA Pro 172)
  • Endpoint types
    • API GTW can be Edge Optimised (default), Regional or Private (within VPC)
  • Security
    • Can load SSL certificates and use R53 to define CNAME
    • Resource policy to control who can access the API GTW
    • IAM roles for the API GTW to invoke any services such as Lambda, or push CW Logs

Step Functions
  • ~Azure Logic Apps
  • Visual serverless workflows as JSON state machine
    • sequences, parallel, conditions, timeouts, error handling...
  • Intergrates with Lamda, EC2, ECS, on premises servers, API GTW, etc..
  • Use cases
    • Great for user approval/interactions, max execution of 1 year
    • Google "Step Functions uses cases"
    • Orchestrate serverless applications and automated DevOps workflows

CI/CD services

  • CodeBuild
    • build.general1.small > 100mn p/m
  • CodePipeline
    • 1 activate pipeline (master only?) p/m
  • CodeDeploy
    • free
  • CodeStar
    • free
  • CodeArtifact
    • 2GB artifacts p/m
  • Tutorial to set up Pipieline:
    • https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/devops/complete-ci-cd-with-aws-codecommit-aws-codebuild-aws-codedeploy-and-aws-codepipeline/
  •  Travis integration with CodeDeploy, AWS S3
    • https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/

CodeCommit
  • Online repository, same as github, bitbucket..
  • But with ability to control who can do what via IAM roles
    • eg. Developers IAM group who can create PRs, Senior Dev group who can merge to master
  • Can enable triggers and notifications
    • CW Events to trigger anything (Lambda, Code commit, etc.) based on CodeCommit changes (PR comment, repo change, etc.)

CodeBuild
  • only 100mn of free build time per month...
  • Build server, same as TeamCity, Travis CI, Jenkins...
  • Steps defined in a buildspec.yaml (instead of .travis.yaml for Travis)
  • Integration with S3/AWS Artifacts, and other AWS services via the buildspec.yaml
    • for eg, to push docker deploy tarballs  etc.)
    • Login to ECR and build/push image
  • Environment variables / Secrets
    • default CodeBuild variables (eg. AWS_REGION, use printenv() command to check them all)
    • Secrets from SSM Parameter store
  • Notifications / Automations
    •  CW events to react from events such as Pipeline state change, failed pipeline notification
      • eg. Trigger SNS, Lambda, rollback deployments, etc.
    • CW alarms to notify if too many build failures, etc.
    • Rules to set a CRON event invoking a CodeBuild project build every X days
  • Monitoring
    • Save CodeBuild logs to CW / S3
  • Security
    • By default it is launched outside of VPC, so CodeBuild can't access resources in a private subnet (RDS, EC2s)
    • Need to specify a VPC configuration in the .buildspec.yaml (VPC/subnet id)
  • Integration with CodeCommit: notify in CodeCommit that "Build has started" after pushing changes
    • google: "Validating AWS CodeCommit Pull Requests with AWS CodeBuild and Lambda"

CodeDeploy
  • To deploy application code to already existing resources (which are not managed by EB): many EC2, ASG, ECS, and Lambda
  • Though it cannot provision CodeDeploy DOES NOT provision any resources
    • Use Cloudformation in CodeBuild to provision resources
    • Make sure EC2 instances have the CodeDeploy agent (via User Data script / cfn-init)
  • Steps defined in appspec.yaml + deployment strategy (SE356)
    • Easily deploy to ASG - actually to a deployment group (set of instance(s) with specific tag(s))
    • Define rolling updates/rollbacks (automatic rollback when a deployment fails)
    • Use hooks to verify deployment state after each deployment phase (BeforeInstall, ValidateService, etc.)
    • Can customise deployment behavior with environment variables eg. DEPLOYMENT_GROUP_NAME==dev
  • Can be easily chained into CodePipeline to use artifacts from S3 (source code, dependencies, etc)
  • CLI
    • `aws deploy push` to push the current directory to S3 as zip (instead of using artifacts) - lecture 23 DevOps (First Deployment) 
  • Notification / Automation
    • Similar to CodeBuild, can use CW events to trigger Lambda / SNS based on CodeDeploy events. eg.
      • if CodeDeploy state ready -> reboot instance
      • CodeDeploy state failed-> terminate instance...
      • Check CW Events with CodeDeploy as a source
    • Can also use alarms, eg monitor CPU, if > 90% following CodeDeploy -> rollback

CodePipeline
  • CodePipeline best practices and lambda uses cases
    • https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codepipeline/latest/userguide/best-practices.html
  • Pipe together all previous services: Github, Codebuild, Codedeploy, cfn, etc
  • Define stages in sequence and/or parallel with optional manual approvals
    • Manual approval stage to review app in dev/uat instance, then deploy to prod upon approval
    • Create/delete resources via cfn stacks
  • Pass artifacts from a stage to another via s3
    • CodePipeline artifacts =! CodeBuild artifacts!!
  • Pipeline can be triggered by
    • Github/CodeCommit: code was pushed
    • ECR for when a new image was pushed
    • S3: artifact was uploaded
  • Could have 2 pipelines:
    • 1st gets triggered on pushed code to repository, invoke CodeBuild to push docker image
    • 2nd gets triggered when new docker image was pushed to ECR
    • Though only 1 pipeline in the Free Tier
  • Pipelines can be defined by CloudFormation templates to be reproducible at scale
    • https://github.com/aws-samples/codepipeline-nested-cfn
    • https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/continuous-delivery-codepipeline-basic-walkthrough.html

CodeStar
  • To integrate all developer tools above in a single view / Dashboard
  • Github, CodeBuild, CodeDeploy, CodePipeline, CF, CW
  • Sits on top of CodePipeline

CodeArtifact
  • To store build artifact and software updates / packages (docker deploy tarballs?)

DevOps / Automation

  • CloudFormation
    • 1k operations p/m
  • CloudFormer
  • AWS Service Catalog
    • free
  • SSM System Manager
    • free
  • SSM Resource Group
    • free
  • SSM Parameter store
    • free
  • Secret Manager
    • not free
  • EC2 Image Builder
    • spins up large instances during build!
CloudFormation
  • Infrastructure as code
    • yaml files reproduce anything to a new region/account in a click
    • create many stack for many layers (nested stacks = best practice)
      • 1 stack for network (VPC)
      • 1 stack for web layer (ELB, EC2, DBs)
      • 1 stack for databases, etc.
    • Export graphical representation of services to support documentation
  • To update an ec2 in an ASGm must create a new LT version first with cfn UpdatePolicy
  • Cost savings
    • can see the cost of a stack
    • Deleting a whole stack when not in use (on schedule, every night)
    • Then re-creating everything automatically in the morning
  • Security
    • ChangeSets to view what would be changed on stack update (~dry run)
    • Use StackPolicies to prevent accidental updates / deletes to stack resources
    • DeletionPolicy (Retain/Snapchot/Delete) to decide what to do with the resources when stack is deleted
  • Many templates on the web! + good documentation
    • http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-template-resource-type-ref.html
    • EC2 example: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/aws-properties-ec2-instance.html
  • CodeBuild integrations to deploy / delete resources before CodeDeploy
  • Advanced Cloudformation
    • cfn-init, cfn-signal (wait conditions), cfn-hup
  • Look at CloudFormation repo for basic stuff + notes in README.md
    • https://github.com/gbourniq/aws-cloudformation-provision-instance/blob/main/cfn-template.yaml

AWS CloudFormer
  • To create cfn templates from existing AWS resources
  • https://medium.com/@ridmag/how-to-use-aws-cloudformer-e8d848cfafe1

AWS Service Catalog
  • For business users (without deep knowledge of AWS) to launch sets of authorised resources
    • Restrict users to select pre-defined config parameters
    • Ensures consistency / standardisation, governance, compliance
  • Use CFN templates behind the scenes uploaded by admins
  • Integration with self services portals such as ServiceNow, MS Forms? (Eigen instance launch form)
  • Can brand the self service portal on AWS (logo, colours etc)

SSM System Manager
  • To manage and install software & patch OS on multiple instances in the cloud / on prem
  • Session Manager
    • to ssh into instances (through IAM) without port 22 open
    • no need for Bastion Hosts
    • all commands are logged to S3/CW
  • SSM Documents (json owned by AWS or custom scripts):
  • Run Command, to run any command (1 line) on the SSM managed instances as a "one off"
    • AWS-ConfigureDocker... Amazing!!! integrate this in Cloudformation template...
    • AWS-RunDockerAction.. to do anything with containers
    • AWS-ConfigureCloudWatch
    • AWS-RunShellScript to run some installation script (eg. sudo yum install -y httpd) to all EC2 in a tagged based SSM resources group
  • Automation: to simplify common maintenance and deployment tasks = list of steps
    • AWS-StopEC2InstanceWithApproval - to request 1+ IAM users approvals, same for restart, etc.
    • AWS-UpdateCloudFormationStackWithApproval ...
    • AWS-UpdateLimuxAmi to create Golden AMI from source AMI !! -> DevOps demo

SSM Inventory
  • Analyse all software installed on all managed instances
  • Great for compliance

SSM Parameter store
  • Store securely any environment variable / secrets used across AWS services
    • string, list, or SecureString
    • Integration with KMS so that the SecureString can only be used by X service / user
    • AWS managed variables, eg. latest Amazon Linux 2 AMI ID (great for cloudformation)
  • Should keep a consistent pattern: /EC2/MYAMI-ID or /my-app/dev/db-url
  • Parameter versioning
  • Can add expiration dates to parameters
  • Powerful CLI (DevOps demo)
    • aws ssm get-parameters... with decryption, by path, by path recursive, by path with decryption
  • Integration with Cloudformation to inject environment variables and secrets at stack runtime
  • Secret Manager is similar to SSM Parameter store
    • + allows for automatic rotation of secrets every X days, via a Lambda function
    • + better integration with RDS, Redshit, DocumentDB, so a little bit more secure
      • Eg. if automatic rotation on RDS password -> RDS will automatically updates its password

EC2 Image Builder
  • Service to build AMIs with predefined software packages
    • eg. Docker, CW agent, Python and AWS CLI + can install custom packages via a yaml file
  • Spin up a "Building" and a "Testing" instance
Monitoring

  • CW Metrics
    • 10 free
  • CW Dashboard
    • 3 free
  • CW Logs
    • Free 5GB S3 storage
  • CW Events / EventBridge
    • 1m calls
  • CW Alarms
    • 10 free
  • CloudTrail
    • 1 Trail free
  • X-Ray
    • 100k recorded traces p/m
  • AWS Config
    • May be expensive!!
  • AWS Chatbot
    • Free
CW Metrics
  • Built-in metrics for every services (Infra monitoring)
    • Must look at all metrics available for common services: EC2, ELB, RDS, Volumes, etc.
    • Eg. AWS managed EC2 metrics: CPU, NetworkIn/Out,  Disk usage, etc.
    • Basic Monitoring (5mm) vs Detailed Monitoring (1mn)
  • Custom metrics (anything user defined)
    • Must install CW unified agent on EC2
    • Pushed to CW (PutMetricData API) with `aws cloudwatch put-metric-data`(DevOps course)
    • Examples of custom metrics
      • RAM usage (hands on SysOps)
      • Number of connected users
      • # connection to ALB, etc
      • must specify value and dimension when pushing a metric
    • Standard resolution (1mn) vs High resolutions (1sec)
  • Metrics (built-in and custom) can be used to trigger CW alarms
  • Create dashboards, view metrics by dimensions (instance id, tags, etc.)
  • Export metrics data to S3 for archival (DevOps demo)
    • Scheduled Lambda function to call `lambda-export-cw-to-s3`

CW Dashboard
  • Multi region, display metrics and alarms
  • Collerate multiple graph into one view, eg
    • CPU utilisation for some instance
    • total monthly cost to date, etc.
  • There are also some AWS managed dashboard, eg
    • EC2 dashboard to show all instances CPU usage

CW Logs
  • Application logs
    • EC2 server logs / Application logs via the CW unified log agent
      • Can configure how logs are sent: by batch_count, batch_duration, batch_size
    • Direct integration for ECS application logs, Beanstalk, API Gateway / Lambda logs
  • Operating System Logs (Event logs, system logs)
    • Generated by the OS
    • Inform of the system behaviour (/var/log/messages or /var/log/auth.log) via the unified CW agent
  • AWS Managed Access Logs (ELB, API GTW, S3, VPC, R53, CT, CF etc.)
    • All logs can be tailed from CLI
    • Logs can be exported to S3 manually
    • Best to automate this using a Cron Lambda function (cheaper option compared to a CW Logs subscription)
  • Security, Cost
    • Set encryption of logs with KMS at the group log level
    • Needs IAM permissions to send logs to CW (from any service or custom app logs)
    • Specify "Expire after X time" at the Log Group level, to not overspend when lots of logs
    • Most secure is to aggregate multi-account logs into a centralised locked AWS account (SA Pro 343)
  • Must enable Metric Filtering earlier than later
    • Filter logs using patterns from an error.log or general.log file, to create custom metrics
      • Eg. DevOps Demo: if too many 404 over 5mn -> trigger alarm
  • Can send logs to
    • S3, Lambda, ElasticSearch, Kinesis Streams/Firehose
    • S3 Export to manually store logs for archival (up to 12 hours so not real time)
    • Use Logs subscription for real-time, but expensive
  • Logs Insights to query logs and add queries to CW Dashboards (~ELK more powerful)

CW Subscription
  • CW Logs real-time processing with Subscriptions, to deliver logs to Kinesis stream, firehose, or lambda
  • A bit expensive?

CW Events
  • Intercept events from almost any AWS services
  • AWS EventBridge is the newer version + allows for external service events from partners (eg. Datadog)
  • Look at most common services in Source/Target, CW Event allows for some really interesting automation!!!
    • Almost ALL AWS services have some kind of integration! CloudFormation, CodePipeline/Commit/Build/Deploy, CodeStar, API Gateway, Lambda, ASG, CT
  • CW Events Sources
    • Schedule (every hour) or Cron (eg. every monday at 5AM)
    • Event patterns from services
      • CodePipeline, Event: Pipeline state changes...
      • EB, ECS, Lambda, VPC logs, API Gateway, CloudTrail based on metric filter, R53 DNS queries
    • CW Alarms cannot be used as a source for CW Events
    • A CW event generates a small JSON with details about the event (show sample data)
    • Using "AWS API Call via CloudTrail" as event (for any service), will allow CW Events to get triggered by
      • almost ALL API calls for ALL services (which are not "List", "Get' or "Describe")
      • Eg. "CreateImage" API can be intercepted to trigger event when AMI created
      • Check out DevOps demo
  • CW Events Targets - Most popular
    • Compute: Lambda = allows to do anything (eg. send slack notification), Batch, ECS, EC2
    • Integrations: SNS for email notifications, SQS Queue
      Orchestration: start a Step Functions, CodePipeline, CodeBuild
    • Maintenance: EC2 actions (terminate, reboot, create snapshot etc)
  • DevOps demo - S3 Events vs CW Events with S3 as a source
    • S3 event allows to intercept Object level operations, eg. "PUT", "GET", etc.
    • CW Events with S3 as a source, allows for both Object AND Bucket level operations (if CT enabled on the bucket)

CW Alarms
  • Very important for DevOps workflows
    • Automatically react to any event from any service, eg.
    • Reboot instance if CPU > 90% for 10 data points across 15m
      • 1. send to SNS (and then SQS/Lambda, etc) and/or email address
      • 2. trigger Auto Scaling action
      • 3. trigger an EC2 action (eg. stop/terminate/reboot/recover instance)
    • Notify/Do something if an instance is Stopped/Terminated/Reboot/Recover
  • Can be triggered by
    • custom metrics
    • aws managed metrics (built-in)
  • ...and target
    • ASG
    • EC2 Actions (recover/stop/reboot instance)
    • SNS/SQS
    • Lambda, etc.
  • CLI
    • For testing alarms `aws set-alarm-state`
  • Billing Alarm available when switching to North Virginia region
    • send notification when spend above monthly limit
    • can also create alarms for specific services (eg. EBS, KMS, Lambda, etc.)

CloudTrail
  • History of all events in account
    • Provides governance, compliance and audit for AWS accounts (enabled by default)
  • Detect unauthorized calls + root cause of changes for the past 90 days
    • Only shows Create/Modify/Delete events
  • Detect unusual activities by streaming CT Logs -> CW Logs -> Metrics Filters -> CW Alarm -> SNS
    • Eg. count occurrences of EC2 TerminateInstances API
    • Use CW Events with CW as a source, to be the most reactive
  • Create a CT trail service to
    • Get detailed events
    • Put logs to CW logs / S3 for analysis with Athena / Quicksights

X-Ray
  • Troubleshooting performance for distributed applications
    • follow in details what happens to an incoming request
    • understand microservices dependencies
    • see where throttling happens
  • Easy to set up (use SDK in application)
  • EC2 needs IAM permissions to write data to X-Ray via the X ray daemon
  • Out of the box for Lambda, ELB, API GTW, ECS, Beanstalk, EC2

AWS Config
  • Record AWS services configurations changes - trigger SNS for any changes, or if non-compliant services
  • Rules
    • 75 managed rules, eg
      • is ssh open to the world for any SG?
      • Unused SGs?
      • Did ALB config changed over time?
      • All ELBs have SSL configured?
    • Can add custom rules, eg
      • period trigger to check all resources are tagged properly
      • Blue print Lambda functions to show compliances on X services
  • Notifications
    • Send compliance overview (all resources) via SNS: what changed, history, etc. 
  • Automated remediation with CW Events, and "ComplianceChangeNotification" event type
    • Automatically react to a non compliant resource created
    • Remediation capability within AWS Config rule -> look for "remediation action"
  • Compliance
    • Logging must be defined at all steps to provide security and compliance (SO 381)
    • CT trails, Config Rules, CW logs for data retention, VPC Flow logs, ELB access logs, CF logs, WAF logs
    • Can be analysed using Athena

AWS Chatbot
  • to send any notification to slack (instead of using a custom Lambda
  • https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/mt/7-awsome-ways-to-use-aws-chatbot/
  • Use Cases
    • Notify Slack on Amazon EC2 CPU usage spike
    • Run AWS Lambda Notify Slack on execution errors
    • AWS Budget notifications on Slack when it exceeds threshold
    • Notify Slack on AWS CodePipeline errors
    • Monitor operations on AWS Systems Manager parameter

Data Engineering
Kinesis Streams/Analytics/Firehose/Video Streams
Glue Catalog
Glue ETL
AWS Batch
Data Stores and Data Pipelines
Athena
Quicksight
Kinesis Streams: low latency streaming ingest at scale
Kinesis Analytics: real time SQL query on top of streams
Kinesis Firehose: loads streams onto S3, Redshift, DHW,
Glue Catalog: schema inference from S3 data and Redshift, RDS
Glue ETL: serveless python/scala code running on Spark, scheduled or triggered
AWS Batch: fully serverless, run from docker images, scheduled (CW) vs. orchestrated (Step Functions)
Data Stores for ML/DE: S3, Redshift, RDS, DynamoDB
Athena: Interactive SQL queries on S3
Quicksight: Visualisations (~PowerBI)
Machine Learning
SageMaker
SageMaker AutoML
Spark MLlib vs. SM built-in algorithms
  • SageMaker is built to handle the entire ML workflow: fetch/clean data -> train/evaluate model -> deploy model/evaluate prod results -> fetch/clean...
  • SageMaker at a high level: S3 training data -> model training instance (running the training code image) -> outputs the model to S3 -> pulled by the inference instance (running the inference code docker image) which exposes an endpoint for predictions with auto scaling as an option
  • SageMaker Notebooks to train models but also manage infrastructure (spin up train instances, create prediction endpoint, etc)
  • SageMaker AutoML: Handles the data preprocessing, algorithm selection, model tuning, and all training infrastructure. Great as a starting point
  • Algorithms: Review briefly the ML course slides
Free Tier AI Services

  • AWS Comprehend
    • 5M chars / month
  • AWS Lex
    • 10k text or 5k speech / month
  • AWS Textract
    • OCR
  • AWS Macie
    • 1GB of processed data overall
  • AWS Polly
    • 5M chars / month
  • AWS Transcribe
    • 60mn of speech / month
  • AWS Translate
    • 2M chars / month
  • AWS Rekognition
    • 5k images / month
Other: AWS Forecast, Personalize, CodeGuru, Kendra, Augmented AI
Comprehend: NLP service to extract intents from text
AWS Lex: Voice and Chat text chatbots
AWS Macie: Discover and Classify sensitive data (PID) eg Names, email addresses etc.
AWS Polly: Text to speech service
AWS Transcribe: Speech to text service
AWS Translate: Translation service
AWS Rekognition: Image recognition service, SA Pro architecture 490

Other good-to-know services:
  • AWS Mechanical Truk (RPA Version)
  • AWS Alexa / Connect / Lex, for automated virtual call center
  • AWS Workspaces
